elements.text: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary
Read for enjoyment, with a focus on the counting sequence.

Count aloud 1–10 items, with one-to-one correspondence; Count out a given number of objects from a group of up to 10 objects; Recognize and name numerals 0–9; Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Say the Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag and the state flag, and observe a moment of silence.
Have children count down as they remove manipulatives one at a time from a group.
Guide children to count the number of items shown on a Number Card.
What book did you choose?  Why did you choose that one?
Use the dress-up clothes to make an outfit for the first day of kindergarten.
Can you count these 10 blocks in order?
Write about your favorite day in preschool. What made it special?
What materials could you use to make the number 9?
Use your finger to trace the letter
What did you build? Why did you build that?

Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice how the characters adapt to change and to review counting.

Count aloud 1–10 items, with one-to-one correspondence; Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Count out a given number of objects from a group of up to 10 objects; Recognize and name numerals 0–9;   Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Have children count a certain number of Connecting Cubes from a group of 10.
Challenge children to transition from working with partners to working independently.
Can you show me how to hold that book?
Can you pretend that it is the first day of kindergarten?
Find the number that shows how old you are.
What games do you hope to play in kindergarten? Write about them.
Make a name tag for your first day of kindergarten. Decorate it however you like.
Write your name on a name tag in big letters. How many letters are in your name?
Build a tower with 10 blocks. Can you count them backwards?

Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary
What is one thing Tom does before starting kindergarten?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension, with a focus on measurement.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Have children tell whether an Activity Card depicts something they do before or after dinner.
Guide children to share and discuss their personal routines.
How do things change in this character’s life?
Pretend you are walking into school on the first day of kndergarten! What do you see?
Count to 10. What number did you count after eight?
How do you think you will feel on your first day of kindergarten?
What are you making? What did you do before you started making that?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word
? Can you draw the letter that makes that sound?
Why do you need to put larger blocks down before you put smaller blocks when you make a tall tower?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas. The chart says, I want to . . . Learn to tie my shoes. Drive a fast train. Be a doctor. Make colorful art.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to discuss what children want to be when they grow up, engage children with movement, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to connect to this week’s concept question,

Count aloud 1–10 items, with one-to-one correspondence; Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Count out a given number of objects from a group of up to 10 objects; Recognize and name numerals 0–9;   Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Vote as part of a group to make decisions.
Show children a number and guide them to build a tower using that many Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to count the Connecting Cubes with one-to-one correspondence.
What do you think this character will be when she grows up?
Pretend to be a teacher! How many students do you have?
Compare these two towers. Which one has more blocks?
What kind of job do you think would be the best for you?
Draw a bag to take to kindergarten. How will you decorate it?
Use your finger to trace the  word
Build a house using blocks. How many blocks did you use? How could you add more?

Use Circle Time to vote on a last activity and engage children in celebratory dance.
Start Story Time revisiting the book
What will you do to get ready for kindergarten?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination, with a focus on measurement.
Count aloud 1–10 items, with one-to-one correspondence; Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Understand that people use different languages to communicate and express simple greetings and phrases in a language other than their own.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Vote as part of a group to make decisions; Say the Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag and the state flag, and observe a moment of silence.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Write a story about a child’s first day at kindergarten.
Imagine that this story continued. What would happen next?
Pretend you are on the kindergarten playground. What will you do?
Count your toes forward and backward.
Imagine you are writing to a child who will be in preschool next year. What will you say?
Use any materials to make something special to remind you of preschool.
Use magnetic letters to make the word
Use blocks to make a school. Where is the kindergarten classroom?

Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recite the Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag and the state flag and observe a moment of silence.

Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Connect their lives to events, times, and routines.
